The Independent was keen on topical references this week: Dac's clue...

4d Education secretary wants heads to recruit right teachers (11)

...for GOVERNESSES could have been an actual headline; Quixote - known locally as Pasquale - tipped his hat to a cricketer-turned-party-leader...

12ac One fellow keeping position, hard politician in Pakistan (5,4)

Device of the week

Wordplay normally makes up half of a clue, but sometimes an audacious setter lets some of the cryptic work slip into the answer itself, in a way that only makes sense to the solver after they've solved it. All cryptic clues have some relation to a rebus, of course, but it's sometimes at one remove, like this Times Jumbo clue...

20ac Isolated position of husband he's put in today and before? (2,3,6,2,7)

...for IN THE MIDDLE OF NOWHERE. Reader yvains nominated Arachne's succinct route...

13ac Opening numbers: 500,000,000,000? (7)

...where 500,000,000,000 denotes "half a trillion" for NOSTRIL. That puzzle also gave the word "alien" a day off from its normal use to indicate ET in an answer, making ALIEN an answer as clued by "Foreign film" and including all the members of the spaceship Nostromo in the Ridley Scott movie somewhere in the grid. The puzzle's annotated solution is now available.

Latter patter

A word used by those who suspect our prime minister of prioritising tennis and country suppers over national wellbeing appeared in Friday's Telegraph Toughie...

13ac It's macabre holding a cross and putting the feet up (10)

...where the sinister surface reading leads to the apparently more benign CHILLAXING. New words like CHILLAX are regarded by some as a kind of cheating at language, especially if they have a suspicious air of fun.

Use is probably the ultimate arbiter and we'll see whether newer frankenwords like FRENEMY, COCACOLONISATION and FAUXHAWK become as unremarkable and unobjectionable as BRUNCH, SMOG and MOTORCADE - or whether they're destined to the same dustbin as the nineteenth-century INSINUENDO and Virginia Woolf's SCROLLOPING, which to my ears has a sound that's too fun to denote "heavily intricate".

This suspicion of the new is not itself new, as Euripides shows in his outburst from Aristophanes' The Frogs:

I know the fellow - know him through and through
Arrogant, wanton savage that he is
Of speech unbridled, passionate, unfenced
A ranting, pompous portmantologist!

And perhaps you think the word itself is an unnecessary coinage, but reader: how would you clue PORTMANTOLOGIST?

Exasperation has set in whenever it rains

Dry days are often followed by wet evenings – in Colombo especially – and there has only been half an hour of leeway to get a game in. So the players and spectators mooch around all day and then are frustrated as the rain descends. VM

TV schedules are sacrosanct

But there is an absurdity here best exemplified by the West Indies and Ireland game. There was a way for them to play that match (start earlier, for example) but instead the Irish were denied the chance of producing an epic performance. Moreover this is an odd time to have a tournament in Sri Lanka. There is the suspicion that the ICC is more interested in a convenient, lucrative tournament than a dry one. VM

There has been a dearth of close games

The usual truism (I've used it myself) is that the shorter the game the more likely the upset. Yet that has not been the case. The analysts of the big teams have set to work. Not much is left to chance. Zimbabwe were thrashed twice, Bangladesh twice, Ireland once, Afghanistan once.

There were too many empty seats at the start (it costs between 14p and 50p to get in) but the crowds are starting to turn up — and they have seen some fine batting, though not by England against India. That was easily the most inept batting by a major side in the tournament so far. It was a macabre performance by England's youthful middle order. They are exciting; they are not reliable. VM

Flash interviews in between innings

What a banal intrusion into what are supposed to be life and death struggles. VM

One final grumble

It is a pain to have to keep an eye and an ear on the punditry of ESPN's Cricket Extra. In fact KP has been rather good – he's starting to enjoy it – but we could do without having to constantly check whether he has committed an indiscretion or not. They say he should not have accepted the ESPN invitation. Have you heard how many 000s there are at the end of his contract? It might be a while before he appears on TMS. VM

There were fine moments too

Afghanistan's performance against India was uplifting, thanks to Shapoor Zadran, the left-arm opening bowler, who prowled around like Goran Ivanisevic. And that helicopter shot from Mohammad Shahzad.

The pitches have been excellent, with sufficient bounce to encourage six-hitting. Yet the good spinners have prospered, especially those with a bit of mystery. Watch out for Sunil Narine, so bland in England for the West Indies, and any of the Indians as well as Saeed Ajmal and Ajantha Mendis. And I have a sneaking feeling the West Indies might pick Samuel Badree, a wrist-spinner from Trinidad, against England (the analysts will have to earn their corn to find much footage of him).

Chris Gayle still adds a frisson whenever he takes guard and check out his training shoes. The heels match his socks so it looks as if he is wearing sandals. Virat Kohli looks in wonderful form, so too Imran Nazir and Nasir Jamshed of Pakistan and New Zealand's Brendon McCullum. VM

Jos Buttler's fielding … Jonny Bairstow's fielding

But we want to applaud their batting. And there was a nice moment at about 12.30am at the Irish hotel after the washed-out game against the West Indies. The supporters and families were milling around the bar when the team returned to the hotel. They broke into a round of spontaneous and constant applause. The Irish had not played particularly well but they loved 'em anyway. VM

Audacity with the bat

How to separate so many sixes? Arguably the most audacious batting moment of the tournament came in the semi final from Umar Gul, who had been Akmal's big-hitting partner in that thrilling finish against South Africa. He came to the crease against Sri Lanka in the 18th over, with Pakistan needing more than two runs per ball – and extravagantly allowed his first delivery from Ajantha Mendis to pass outside off stump. AW

Best innings

Marlon Samuels in the final is a bit too obvious. I preferred Umar Akmal's unbeaten 43 from 41 balls to steer Pakistan to an unlikely Super Eights victory over South Africa, after they had apparently been down and out at 76 for seven. AW

Penalty shoot-out here to stay

Both the Super Over deciders in the Super Eights were good fun (unless you're a New Zealander), confirming beyond doubt that cricket's more satisfying version of a penalty shoot-out is here to stay. The West Indies win against them, sealed by a Samuels six after Tim Southee had opened up with a no-ball from which Chris Gayle also cleared the ropes, was a first indication that their name might be on the trophy. AW

And how to improve the tournament?

I'd go for two groups of six, with the top two from each qualifying for the semi finals. This would allow the tournament to start with a bang, as opposed to the damp squib in the current system, make every game meaningful, and give the less-fancied countries – Ireland, Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Zimbabwe – more of a crack. AW

Karl Popper died in 1994. As I remarked in the initial article in this series, his thought is, in many ways, too close for us to be able to evaluate with the full benefit of hindsight. But what would Popper make of the new(ish) millennium? It is hard not to believe that he would be cast into despair. Knowledge claims (and, more than that, certainty claims) are being made not only throughout political and religious ideologies, but also within alternative therapies, 2012 cults, revisionist approaches to history and a host of other fields.

Let's remind ourselves of Popper's actual take on this: he does not suggest that we reject these sorts of claims wholesale, but he does insist that we do not refer to them either in terms of epistemological certainty or in terms of science. They may, one day, achieve full falsifiable rigour, or they may not; they may be useful in other respects, or they may not, but we must be clear about their epistemological status.

So let us now take a step back and consider whether Popper has been successful in establishing falsificationism as the methodology du jour. Here, I think, we must acknowledge that he has not. Probabilistic induction remains the methodology of choice, not only among scientific practitioners, but also among those philosophers of science who take more moderate stances of other philosophers of science. Falsificationism also comes under fire from the scientific establishment itself, for instance, in the work of physicists Alan Sokal and Jean Bricmont, who state:

"When a theory successfully withstands an attempt at falsification, a scientist will, quite naturally, consider the theory to be partially confirmed and will accord it a greater likelihood or a higher subjective probability… But Popper will have none of this: throughout his life he was a stubborn opponent of any idea of 'confirmation' of a theory, or even of its 'probability' … [yet] the history of science teaches us that scientific theories come to be accepted above all because of their successes." (Sokal and Bricmont, 1997)

Both astrology and astronomy make incorrect predictions, Sokal and Bricmont argue, and falsificationism does not differentiate between them. But this claim is disputed by writers such as David Miller, who bring us full circle by pointing out that astronomy contains the parameters for its own falsifiability, whereas astrology does not.

What of Popper's political thought – that body of work so closely intertwined in Popper's writings with epistemology and scientific enquiry? His views on tolerance and anti-totalitarianism do now look like common sense to many. Political and social tolerance clearly leads to a paradox: summed up in the issue of where one person's fist ends and another's nose begins. Popper was a champion of liberalism throughout his life. He argues that tolerance means that we may eventually fail to tolerate intolerance. We can contain intolerant political philosophies, he says,

"… as long as we can counter them by rational argument and keep them in check by public opinion."

However:

"We should therefore claim, in the name of tolerance, the right not to tolerate the intolerant. We should claim that any movement preaching intolerance places itself outside the law, and we should consider incitement to intolerance and persecution as criminal."

These are opinions which are highly relevant to today's relativistic, pluralistic societies, in which political and cultural boundary settings are still of necessity emergent, imprecise and fluid. Here, epistemological claims of certainty cannot be applied and Popper's early and tragic encounters with the results of those claims – on both sides of the political spectrum – surely informed his commitment to as great a degree of mutual tolerance as possible. Nor is this incompatible with his commitment to falsifiability as a standard for scientific rigour: fallibilism underlies both the knowledge claims of science and those of politics.

"The old scientific ideal of episteme – of absolutely certain, demonstrable knowledge – has proved to be an idol. The demand for scientific objectivity makes it inevitable that every scientific statement must remain tentative for ever. It may be corroborated, but every corroboration is relative to other statements which, again, are tentative. Only in our subjective experiences of conviction, in our subjective faith can we be 'absolutely certain'."

The "craving to be right", that hostility to tolerance which is found throughout all human inquiry, is in Popper's eyes the basis for totalitarian thought; only once that is rejected can we get down to the business of testing truth claims, and only then can we be honest about what we do and do not know.

Christian Bale has returned to the role of a shyster hired by the FBI to take down corrupt politicians in David O Russell's forthcoming conman drama.

Bale, who won the best supporting actor Oscar for his turn as boxer Dicky Eklund in Russell's The Fighter, was reported to have left the project earlier this year, but has now signed on. The as-yet-untitled film is also due to star The Fighter's Amy Adams, along with Bradley Cooper and Jeremy Renner.

Like The Fighter, Russell's new film is based on a true story, though there appear to be significant differences between real-life events and the version playing out on screen. Eric Warren Singer's screenplay for the movie, which was once titled American Bullshit, is described as being "based on the true story of a financial con artist (Bale) and his mistress/partner in crime (Adams), who were forced to work with an out-of-control federal agent (Cooper) to turn the tables on other con artists, mobsters, and politicians. At the epicenter of the tale is the volatile leader of the New Jersey state assembly (Renner) who is also the local hero and mayor of impoverished Camden".

The plot bears a resemblance to – and was previously reported to be based on – the famous Abscam stings in the late 1970s and 80s, which saw a US senator and five congressman convicted as part of a public corruption investigation. Several saw jail time. The stings were overseen by Melvin Weinberg, a convicted con artist who had been hired by the FBI to target others. They involved a "fake sheikh" apparently trying to buy his way into the US by involving public officials in an investment scheme, which often involved the politicians steering public contracts in the sheikh's direction or helping him to bypass regulations.

Weinberg himself avoided a three-year jail sentence for his previous activities and was paid $150,000 for his part in the operations. The "sheikh" was known as Kambir Abdul Rahman – hence the Abscam tag. The New Jersey state assembly leader to be played by Renner would appear to be an amalgam of the various politicians convicted in the stings.

"David has put together an incredible ensemble of actors for what is going to be a powerful and emotional drama about one of the most memorable cast of characters in recent history," producer Charles Roven told the Wrap. The film is due to shoot in mid-February on the US east coast.

Google's unilateral change to its privacy policy in March will come under fire from European data protection commissioners within days, sources say.

The controversial changes, in which Google tied together the previously separate data collected under services including its search engine, YouTube and Google+ were announced in January and implemented two months later. While creating a unified privacy policy across all the services, it also in effect amassed the data into a single location.

That attracted widespread criticism – and now the group of 30 data protection commissioners from across the European Union are believed to have determined that Google has breached EU privacy laws.

Now Google might be required to undo the changes – although Auke Haagsma, a lawyer advising the lobby group Icomp, which is critical of Google's policies, said that would be like trying to "unscramble the egg".

Data protection commissioners in a number of countries have varying powers. The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) in the UK declined to comment on the decision, but said that generally it can use its powers to force any company that breaks the law in altering its privacy policy to reverse the change. "We can issue an enforcement notice," said a spokesperson.

The internet firm is already being investigated by the European commission's competition arm, which says that the way it orders its search results, uses other sites' content, and controls some elements of advertising is anti-competitive.

The two sides have been locked in negotiations since July. Joaquín Almunia, the EC competition commissioner, warned Google in September that it could face court action if it was not more flexible in the negotiations.

Some German data protection authorities are also considering their response to the news that Google has not destroyed all the data its Street View cars collected when they scanned Wi-Fi networks in houses and businesses adjacent to roads.

The changes to Google's privacy policies had already been described as being possibly in breach of EU law by the justice commissioner, Viviane Reding, in March.

Data protection commissioners, led by the French national agency CNIL, criticised Google at the time for making the change without offering consumers the chance to opt out by remaining with the existing policy. The only choices Google offered users were to move to the new policy, or delete their entire user profile. The CNIL and others wanted them to be offered the option of remaining with the existing segmented profile.

Google said at the time that the changes would simplify the experience of using its services and that it was confident that they respected "all European data protection laws and principles". It said users would benefit because it would be able to tailor search results and advertising more specifically to users.

Google declined to comment.

At the end of the second world war, the western allies shared an understandable desire to cement lasting international peace after a conflict that had cost so many lives. One of the most effective ways of achieving this, it was believed, was to ensure the economic growth of all countries. The ideas of US economic historian Walt W Rostow, particularly those in his 1960 book, The Stages of Economic Growth, represented one of the most influential attempts to systematise these thoughts.

The product of a decade's work, the book gives us post-second world war development economics in a nutshell – or rather in the silver sweep of a DC-8 airliner cabin, since Rostow's primary analogy was that of "take off": an aeronautical rendering of the moment when, with sufficient capital and other preconditions in place, "the old blocks and resistances to steady growth are finally overcome".

For Rostow, encouraging this process meant promoting new "enclaves of modern activity" that could be economically fused together to become the nation's "normal condition … built, as it were, into its habits and institutional structure".

Like other modernisation theories, The Stages of Economic Growth was both a diffusionist and technocratic doctrine, since it sought to replicate within more traditional societies the benefits of rationality and progress already experienced in the wealthier parts of the world. It was an approach to development in which a group of experts sitting in their government offices would call forth the machinery of industrialisation and urbanisation to remake social relations on the ground.

If this paternalist rendering of the economic trajectory of nations had a clear moral compass, it had a clear political compass too – just look at the book's subtitle: An Anti-Communist Manifesto. This brings home an important point about development: its inherently political nature. Development policy from the Marshall plan onwards was a form of cold war ideological arm-wrestling. It allowed Soviets and Americans to test who had the better theories for social and economic progress in the Petri dish of the "third world", as it was then known, while allowing them to lay claim to the world's political space without wading into wholesale colonialism in the process.

A graduate of Yale at the precocious age of 19, a contributor to the Marshall plan, and a speechwriter for President Dwight Eisenhower – in addition to being a tenured economist – Rostow was one of the brightest minds to challenge the USSR. When, in 1960, after reading The Stages of Economic Growth, John F Kennedy recruited the hawkish young Rostow to his election team, he would have his chance.

Kennedy bought wholesale into what became known as the "Rostow doctrine", and the decade that followed – the first decade of development in UN parlance – ensured that Rostow's ideas about modernisation spread far and wide.

In the early 1960s the two-year-old Cuban revolution switched first its sugar quota and then its political allegiance from the US to the Soviet Union, helping Rostow's cause by reminding the US what was at stake in its dealings with the developing world. It helped him to promote Kennedy's flagship Alliance for Progress in Latin America, and then, under Lyndon Johnson, to justify US military policy in Vietnam.

For Rostow, aid was always a weapon: something to be targeted rather than delivered. But for all his hawkishness over Vietnam he was adamant, too, that America's political ambitions were ultimately best pursued "crabwise", as he put it, through specific policies and programmes.

However, within a year of Rostow's book being published, some of those developing nations, tired of being scrapped over in a struggle not of their own making, clubbed together to form the Non-Aligned Movement: the first attempt to create a political bloc in the developing world.

Even at its point of greatest influence, then, there was resistance to the politically laden and overdetermining visions of utopia in which modernisation theorists like Rostow traded. And by the end of the 1960s, Rostow was unceremoniously put out to grass: felled in the end by his unflinching commitment to the war in Vietnam. But there is no doubting that, until then, Rostow stood firmly at the helm of the burgeoning field of international development.

Today the ideas, practice and perhaps especially the politics of development have moved on. Rostow's brash optimism (though maybe not his hawkishness) seems somehow out of place in our post-millennial world of "poverty reduction" and "complex humanitarian emergencies". Certainly most practitioners today, though not all, are more wary of assuming European and American history to be the norm, or of reading development as a linear or cumulative process.

But Rostow's view that a dynamic private sector was to be supported by a strong but market-friendly state can still be found in many of today's public-private partnership models. And anyone even slightly informed on World Bank and IMF policies over the past 20 years will see the persistence of his belief that political influence is best delivered under the radar of economic investments. In these and other ways, the Rostovian crab keeps clambering on, a full half century later.

Surviving fashion week as a feminist and a model is no small task. Often the only thing potentially lower than your self-esteem is your blood sugar, as you literally run around London, or Paris, or whatever city you are in.

It is physically and mentally draining, politically confusing and incestuous. With a myriad of stereotypes populating the media as to what models do and therefore are; maintaining an identity as a recent graduate who models to pay the rent, rather than just "a model", is a fine line to tread.

Everyone has their own impression as what fashion week might be like for the models and it tends to fall into two main categories: the cocaine-riddled, fur-clad, sunglasses-wearing (even when its raining) deities who float from car to show; or the starving Latvian teenager who fights her way through the cattle market with minimal English. There is definitely sufficient fuel for the stereotype fire, but fashion week for most models is a particularly subjective experience. It changes from city to city, season to season, and from girl to girl, so this is a riot grrrl's attempt at explaining fashion weeks and tentatively suggesting that fashion and feminism are not mutually exclusive.

London fashion week actually starts in August for those of us women with hips who "need"' to start exercising. This brings us to the huge and complicated issue of weight. Damn. Years of modelling has led to years of being accused of sustaining myself with cocaine and apples, which is both boring and untrue. Why and how models are thin and who makes them so is far too big an issue to deal with here. Body prescriptivism aside, I exercised a bit more in the run-up to fashion week because it made me feel more confident about being examined like a bit of meat. In general I seem to spend a lot of time justifying my existence as a "real" woman, (thanks to Dove and "Colleen's real women") so the next person who tells me that there are no "real" people/feminists on the runways, I will shout at. I am a real person, I eat real food, read real books and play real (bad) guitar. Cogito ergo sum, bitch.

So, after I've pinched myself repeatedly to check that I exist, it's September and the castings have started and with them much running around like a crazy woman and singing Bikini Kill on the tube to keep up morale, because this is where it gets a bit more mentally tough.

There is a lot of rejection. Obviously, no one is defined by how they look, nor should they be, but after a few days of brutality, subject to the whims of some body fascist or sour-faced woman, it can be hard to separate how you look from who you are. However, I am going to take this opportunity to smash my tiny violin: there are some really awesome casting directors and stylists in London who treat you as a person and give you chocolate and/or coconut water when you go to their castings.

One important thing to me as a feminist in fashion week was how I chose to dress. Virginia Woolf wrote about sartorial signifiers of rank for women in Three Guineas, and there is definitely a hierarchy for models during the shows. The basic uniform is tight back jeans, vest/tank top, leather jacket and enormous bag. Cue the tedious military metaphor: your basic privates can be seen changing their shoes from flats to heels on the street in Hackney; while the lieutenants (the girls with drivers) only have to walk in and out, barely scuffing the soles of the designer shoes they were probably given rather than bought. You might not even see a general or major until the shows actually start, as they are probably walking Calvin Klein and London is pretty small fry comparatively. Besides, no one has ever seen an Hermès bag in real life (NB: can a handbag that costs more than a deposit on a house actually exist?).

I chose DMs and a kilt from Camden, not only because I have an overdeveloped love of the 1990s and an underdeveloped adult dress sense, but because in a sea of photographers and bloggers, the way you dress communicates immediately. If your job is based on how you look, I'd like to make my exterior an accurate representation of my interior.

On and off the catwalk, models are slaves to the gaze and while I can't control what I'm paid to wear, I can try off-duty to convey a sense of myself, (which is probably why I'm never in those street-style blogs.) Reiterating how bad fashion can be doesn't help the positive voices within who have gone behind enemy lines. There are some intelligent, creative and kind feminists working their way up the fashion ladder (promise!) who should be lauded and encouraged. While they climb, I suggest drinking as much free champagne as possible and talking very loudly about Hélène Cixous or Judith Butler in front of Anna Wintour. If this doesn't make fashion more feminist-friendly, at least you could be sick on her shoes.

Many commentators and friends have highlighted Malcolm Wicks' dedication, commitment and integrity, as well as his sardonic wit and humour.

He was a rare politician who had prior experience of being a civil servant (in the home office), and of academia (at Brunel and York universities). However, he was not content to reside in an ivory tower and his leadership of the independent thinktank the Study Commission on the Family (1978-82), and of its successor body the Family Policy Studies Centre (1983-92) was concerned with informing public debate and shaping policy reform.

Both organisations produced highly respected analytical and non-partisan research on family trends and considered their implications for public policy.

For his former colleagues – myself included – in those days before the internet and email, Friday afternoons spent stuffing press releases into envelopes, typically aided by Wicks providing a bottle of wine to encourage staff participation, and then physically dropping them around Fleet Street news desks were a regular feature.

When he entered the Commons in 1992, Malcolm had already established a reputation for rigour in his analysis and for knowing his facts and figures, and this was a distinguishing feature of his style throughout his political career, somewhat to the early consternation of his ministerial speech writers.

Malcolm's work in the early 1970s on the problems of the "old and cold", and the plight of older people who face fuel poverty and struggle to heat their homes every winter remained a central preoccupation, and one that he was able to address when he served as energy minister between 2005-8.

He will be remembered for many things, but his achievement in taking a private member's bill through the house and seeing it become legislation in the 1995 Carers (Recognition and Services) Act stands out.

For the first time, the act was concerned with people caring for relatives and friends and providing them with the daily support they needed to continue to remain in the community. It was an important first step in ensuring that the rights and needs of carers were recognised in legislation and it created a significant foundation for subsequent policy and practice.

Four years later a national strategy for carers was introduced for the first time ever, and would never have happened without the Wicks Act. On a copy of the act that he gave me when it received Royal Assent on 28 June 1995 he had written in the margin "no longer forgotten?"

Support for carers is still far from perfect, but the fact that it is now virtually unthinkable for social care policy not to include carers in any developments, and that people are far more carer-aware when looking at policy impact, owes much to the legacy of the Wicks Bill.

Speaking at a seminar at the House of Commons organised by the Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) on 24 April this year, Malcolm set out a vision for a 21st century social welfare system in a lecture on rights, wrongs and responsibilities.

He began, as he often did, by looking back at the lessons of history (something that relatively few of his parliamentary colleagues appear to have much awareness of), and citing once again the giant evils of want, disease, ignorance, squalor and idleness that remained to be vanquished.

He pointed out that a modern Beveridge would surely have also recognised long-term care as one of the important risks to be covered by social insurance through a sharing of costs between the individual and the state.

His argument that a future model for social security and a new social contract should restore "the importance of the contributory principle as a key building block" was timely and prescient, and the core concept of citizenship finds reinforcement in Ed Miliband's speech to the Labour Conference seeking to position Labour as the new "one-nation party".

Sadly, Malcolm's illness and his shockingly early death aged only 65 have prevented him from playing a fuller role in developing his vision for a new system of welfare.

However, the central themes of citizenship, rights and responsibilities, grounded on a clear foundation of values and principles seeking greater equality, empowering individuals rather than reinforcing dependency and promoting social cohesion, provide a powerful and informed analysis for others to inherit "to carry the fire and light the spark".

Malcolm Hunt Wicks 1 July 1947 – 29 September 2012. He is survived by his wife Margaret, his children Roger, Caroline and Sarah and by seven grandchildren.

Donations in Malcolm's memory are being made to Carers UK.

Cornwall may be most famous for its beautiful coast, but there is more to the south-west corner of the UK than tourism and hospitality.

Those considering starting a business in Cornwall would be welcomed by a vibrant community of small businesses and plenty of resources to help them get started.

"The small business network here is very close and tight. Everybody is always willing to help each other," says Charlotte Parker, the founder of cleaning business Charlie's Angels. "There's a great community spirit. I work alongside lots of other small businesses and we support each other."

From a population of 500,000 there are currently 22,000 VAT-registered businesses. Nearly all of them are small and medium-sized. "All but 60 of these businesses are SMEs," says Kim Conchie, the chief executive of Cornwall Chamber of Commerce. "We estimate that there are at least as many small businesses below the VAT threshold, but there is no way of knowing exactly how many smaller businesses there are throughout the region."

Conchie says the business community in Cornwall is very broad. "Businesses range from the bedrock industries you'd expect to see in Cornwall, such as food and tourism, as well as those with mining heritage," he explains. "But we also have vibrant groups of more modern industries including knowledge-based businesses as well as those in marine renewables."

Plenty of talent

A growing graduate population means there is a rich talent pool and Cornwall is well above the national average in terms of qualifications held by its residents. Many graduates choose to stay in the region after completing their degrees.

"There's no doubt that Cornwall is an attractive place to live and work in, which, in turn, means there's no shortage of skills and talent in the county – particularly in growth sectors like IT, renewable energy and aerospace," says Alison Elvey de Rios, a manager at Invest in Cornwall. "The launch of the south west marine energy park earlier this year will consolidate much of the expertise we have in marine energy, helping Cornish businesses in the sector grow and expand into international markets. In the aerospace sector, the new Aerohub enterprise zone at Newquay Airport is set to create up to 2,500 jobs by attracting businesses that will benefit from a simplified planning system and business rate discounts."

One entrepreneur who has successfully taken advantage of Cornwall's hospitality heritage is Ben Hawkins, who launched bakery Da Bara with his brother last year. They have since scooped big clients including Jamie Oliver's Fifteen restaurant in Watergate Bay.

"My brother and I both have a background in the hotel and catering trade and we started our business specifically targeting that sector," he says. "We started out on a part-time basis baking at the weekend and test-traded that way. We set up a little industrial unit in our spare time and launched full-time six weeks after. It has gone really well."

Happier days

Cornwall has come through some bleak periods of high unemployment after the decline of traditional mining and fishing industries. Identified as an Objective One region by the European Union in 1999, the county received £350m in funding to revive its fortunes. Eight years later, in 2007, still deemed to have an economy below the EU average, the region was awarded Convergence status and received a further £415m to develop the local economy through investment in people and infrastructure.

This funding means that there is now a solid business-ready infrastructure in place. Already there is 97% broadband coverage and by 2014, the £132m Next Generation Broadband project will bring Europe's fastest broadband connectivity to Cornwall.

There are plenty of encouragements for prospective startups, with an array of organisations offering practical and financial support. "In the current economic climate, the financial help available to businesses locating in Cornwall is particularly compelling," says Elvey de Rios. "The county provides some of the highest levels of business support and grants in the UK, such as the Grant for Business Investment, which offers up to 50% matched funding."

Startup support

When launching Da Bara, Hawkins received startup support from Outset Cornwall, a free programme for people who have a business idea and need help to get it off the ground. "While we were doing the part-time baking, I went along to Outset Cornwall every week to attend their intensive startup course. It helped so much, especially with pricing our products. I think we'd have struggled without their help," he says.

He has enjoyed being part of the vibrant group of small businesses in the county. "It is very active. Our business is on a small estate and there are lots of very small businesses. There are no empty units here."

However, it is a competitive environment, he explains. "With a smaller population you have to try that little bit harder to bring in enough money."

On the upside, the smaller population also means that things move at a slower pace, which can be helpful for startups, says Parker. "If you are in a bigger place like London and Bristol it may be harder to get all the support you need because people don't have the time, they are so busy. But in Cornwall it is a lot more laid back and there is time for people to sit back and listen and give each other great tips," she explains.

Of course, it's impossible to talk about starting a business in Cornwall without mentioning the quality-of-life factor. Whether starting a new business or relocating an existing venture, Cornwall is bound to delight you with its 300 miles of stunning coastline and beautiful inland moors, combined with low rates of crime and more daylight hours than any other part of the UK.

Hawkins says the quality of life is a highlight of running his own business in the area. "The cost of living is fairly high, but Cornwall is a lovely place to be. It is nice and quiet and being able to go to the beach when you are not working is great," he says.

Labour activists will have left Manchester with a warm glow as far as the NHS is concerned. The shadow health secretary, Andy Burnham, was cheered to the rafters in meeting after meeting as he committed to repealing the reviled 2012 Health and Social Care Act, and prolonged applause greeted leader Ed Miliband as he pledged "an end to the free market experiment" with the NHS.

So far so good, and it would doubtless be tricky at this stage of the political cycle for Labour to set out a detailed strategy on exactly what this involves and how it will be achieved. However, it is important to be hard-headed about all of this. There is a world of difference between Burnham's emphatic tweet ("I'll repeal the act. Full stop") and the reality of unpicking fiendishly complex legislation.

The first caveat is that the pledge is to repeal only those sections of the act concerned with the promotion of markets and competition – part 3. This is certainly the right place to start, for this is where the act is pernicious and why Lansley wanted to cement his reforms in legislation. Monitor, the misnamed Co-operation and Competition Panel, Any Qualified Provider (AQP) and the 49% private patient cap would all presumably be swept away.

This leaves a lot of things still in place – clinical commissioning groups (CCGs), commissioning support units, joint strategic needs assessments, health and wellbeing boards, health and wellbeing strategies and the transfer of some public health functions to local government. Interestingly, these are largely the concessions Lansley made to the Liberal Democrats to keep them on board with his part 3 reforms. Keeping all of these is consistent with Burnham's parallel pledge at the conference – no more structural change. "I don't need new organisations," he said. "I will simply ask those I inherit to work differently."

This is where it starts to get tricky. The new buzz word is "integration", which is currently (at best) the junior ideology in the NHS act. Burnham would put this centre stage. He talks enthusiastically of the need to holistically combine "the social, the mental and the physical" and says all options must be considered – "full integration of health and social care", "one budget, one system".

How this can be achieved without substantial structural change is unclear. Burnham seems to be saying that local authorities will take the commissioning lead for integrated care, but where does this leave the new kids on the commissioning block, CCGs? Putting local authorities into the NHS driving seat is a radical notion, especially at a time when they have little purpose other than to implement central government cuts. There could be an attractive case made for elevating health and wellbeing boards into local whole-system bodies with real powers and budgets, but not without structural upheaval.

There is a further problem strewed across the path of repeal. By 2016, once the election dust has settled, private companies will be well embedded in the NHS. As research for the Labour Party is showing, the AQP strategy is already resulting in private companies winning large long-term contracts, especially for community health services. In four years time the private sector will be strongly embedded in the NHS and Labour will need to think how the situation can be retrieved. Refusing to renew contracts will take time and be messy, while uncompensated sequestration would presumably be a goldmine for lawyers. And what of NHS assets already sequestered and sold by the new government property company, PropCo?

Finally there is the whole issue of exposure of the NHS to UK and EU competition law. Labour's plan is to remove the NHS from the edicts of competition law, but this might be harder than expected. In his book,Never Again, Nick Timmins reveals even back in 2006, as Labour was creating an NHS price list, re-introducing choice, commissioning independent sector treatment centres and encouraging competition between NHS and private hospitals, Norman Warner, the health minister of state in the Lords, had asked for a legal opinion. While heavily qualified, it said the combination of these changes certainly opened up the possibility that the courts would decide that EU law applied.

This suggests that getting rid of Monitor would not be sufficient. The European Court has already ruled that the Spanish NHS is not subject to EU competition rules because it "operates according to the principle of solidarity". Indeed this is why neither Wales nor Scotland will be encumbered by EU law. This sounds exactly what Labour would want for the NHS, but it might mean having to go even further by abolishing Foundation Trust status, reintegrating the NHS family and eradicating the purchaser-provider split introduced in the Thatcher years. Now that would really put a smile on the faces of most conference delegates.

The largest investor in BAE Systems has thrown the defence contractor's proposed €35bn (£28bn) merger with EADS into doubt by raising "significant reservations" in a detailed critique that questions the logic, financial benefit and security implications of the deal.

Invesco Perpetual, which owns 13.3% of the company, took the unusual step of going public with its concerns on Monday morning, ahead of Wednesday's UK takeover panel deadline to thrash out an agreement between BAE and EADS.

Invesco said it could not see the rationale for the merger between a British defence business and the owner of Airbus. "Other than diversification – which investors can achieve for themselves more cheaply and simply – Invesco does not understand the strategic logic for the proposed combination," the fund management firm said.

Invesco's intervention, which echoes concerns raised by the EADS shareholder Lagardère and Conservative MPs, makes it likely that there will be an extension to the Wednesday deadline. In a point-by-point critique, Invesco added that the deal would "materially jeopardise" BAE's position in the US defence market; the proposed holding of stakes by the French and German governments would result in a business driven by politics and not shareholder value; and there would be lower dividends for BAE shareholders in the future.

"Invesco has, on and off, owned shares in BAE for over 20 years. Invesco believes BAE is a strong business with distinctive positions in the global defence market (especially in the US and UK) and good standalone prospects. We look forward to discussions with the board of BAE and other BAE shareholders in the coming days."

Invesco's intervention comes as the British, French and German governments hold further talks on Monday in an attempt to break the impasse over the merger. Sources close to the proposed combination of Britain's largest defence contractor and the owner of Airbus admitted that both companies are likely to seek an extension to the deadline. One source said it was "less likely than more likely" that a deal will be reached by Wednesday, although the granting of more time by the panel is considered a formality given the complexities of the merger. "The betting is on an extension being applied for," said the source.

EADS's and BAE's advisers have made preparations for an extension, while playing down reports from Germany last week that intergovernmental talks over the deal are on the verge of collapse. The French and German governments each control 22.35% of EADS through direct and indirect shareholdings, while the British government can block the transaction through a golden share in BAE that allows it to prevent foreign ownership of the business.

Talks to protect those national interests have hit difficulties after a conference call between government representatives on Friday saw Germany stun France and the UK with a request that the headquarters of the combined business be based in Munich. Germany is also seeking a guarantee from Paris that its stake in the new company will not be larger than 9%, the same size as Berlin's proposed stakeholding.

The three governments will make a further attempt to settle their differences in a conference call on Monday. The British representatives on the call will include Bernard Gray, the Ministry of Defence's head of procurement, with France represented by Emmanuel Macron, an adviser to President François Hollande, and Germany by Lars Hendrik-Röller, chief economic adviser to the chancellor, Angela Merkel.

The UK defence secretary, Philip Hammond, warned on Sunday that the government will block the deal if there is excessive French and German control of the business. Such a scenario is also expected to trigger a US veto of the deal, with the Pentagon's approval still needed because it is BAE's biggest single customer.

"We want to see this company … prospering as a commercial business, focused on doing things that are right for the business, not beholden to or controlled by any one government," Hammond told BBC Radio 4.

Indicating that the government would allow some French and German ownership, he added: "It is not necessary to have no French or German government interest in the company. It is necessary to reduce that stake below the level at which it can control or direct the way the company acts."

The chancellor, George Osborne, told Sky News that the deal must protect UK jobs, with EADS and BAE employing more than 50,000 staff in Britain and representing the country's biggest manufacturing employer. "Our priorities are of course the national security of the United Kingdom. Second: jobs and investment in the UK."

I didn't always see myself as a lawyer at an international law firm, but that's the path my career has taken. Here are the lessons I learned while at university about securing my future in the legal profession.

First year – do your research and remember your first year grades count

Some of my colleagues always wanted to be lawyers. Others, like me, were not so sure. When I started my law degree I knew it would open up lots of opportunities and potential career paths but I didn't really know much about law firms or what life as a lawyer would entail.

While researching, I discovered lots of events to help students gain an insight into the legal profession. A friend told me about one that works with students from a variety of different backgrounds who are interested in a legal career. I applied for one and a fantastic opportunity followed where I spent time meeting people from City law firms, visiting their offices and finding out first-hand what it takes to follow in their footsteps.

My advice would be to do as much research as possible into the opportunities to learn more about careers in law. Many firms run early insight programmes and open days; attend as many of those as possible. They crystallised my decision to become a lawyer, and gave me a really good insight into what to do next. They also gave me the confidence to apply for vacation schemes. I looked objectively at the criteria – a strong academic profile and a genuine interest in the law and commerce – and realised that there is a level playing field if you put yourself forward.

It may seem premature to start visiting careers fairs in your first year, but they are a great place to begin your research. Talking to law firm representatives and listening to their presentations will give you a really good insight into whether a career in the law is for you and how to go about getting one; their websites will list when they are planning to visit your campus. If you make a good impression, ask the right questions and build a rapport with the law firm graduate recruitment team members, it can really stand you in good stead (they have great memories).

With all the other distractions that university life offers, it's easy to succumb to the perception that your first year exam results don't matter, especially if they don't count towards your overall degree grade. This couldn't be further from the truth if you are thinking about a career in the law. When I came to apply for vacation schemes, I quickly discovered that your first year exam results are very important; they are the most recent academic profile that firms have to go on. If you apply yourself, it should pay off.

Second year – get some experience and a foot in the door

If you are serious about a career in law, the best thing you can do is apply for a vacation scheme in your second year at university.

Don't be fooled into thinking you have all the time in the world. The sooner you start applying the better. Not only will it give you more time to tailor your application to the firm you are applying to (beyond substituting one law firm name for another), but it's a huge relief to hear that you've secured a place on a vacation scheme before some of your friends have even applied.

With so many students boasting a strong academic record, securing a vacation scheme is about more than just exam results. It's important to do something beyond academics to talk about at interview and to prove that you're a well-rounded candidate. I mentored young people through a London School of Economics scheme to help raise young people's aspirations and encourage them to apply to university. It equipped me with useful skills such as problem solving, which I use everyday as a lawyer, and gave me lots of examples to use during the interview process.

If you are successful in securing a vacation scheme placement, prepare for the work to be quite different to your degree. I found that my degree mainly focused on theoretical concepts, whereas in practice how to apply the law matters.

Also make the most of the opportunities that firms create during this time to talk to lawyers and find out which firm is the place you want to forge your long-term career. My vacation scheme at Freshfields was a good mix of seminars and on-the-job experience. I was given real work to do and had regular contact with a range of lawyers, from trainees to partners. It's not all work though, a lot of effort is put into organising social events. They are a great way to network informally with people who could become colleagues in a few years.

Usefully, many law firms give you the opportunity to interview for a training contract place during or shortly after your vacation scheme so treat the whole scheme like an extended interview. Show enthusiasm and the ability to work well in a team and you could turn work experience into a training contract.

Third year. Focus on exams and prepare for law school

All being well, by the time you get to your third year, you've already got a training contract in the bag. But don't despair if that's not the case. Law firms do take on graduates who have not done a vacation scheme, (there are usually more training contracts available than places on vacation schemes) but obviously the more experience you have to talk about at interview the better.

Sayo Ogundele is a newly qualified solicitor at Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer
